App description:
Take a trip into orbit and experience life on board the International Space Station!  In this Emmy-nominated simulation, learn how to move and work in zero-gravity using your controllers.  Dock a space capsule, take a spacewalk, and let real NASA astronauts guide you on the ISS through informative videos and images.

Gamepad not supported.

Was skeptical but immediately was blown

The details are amazing, I had low expectations coming from PSVR and playing their space games I thought this was the same experience, I was wrong. The visuals are so crisp and seem photo realistic. You may experience mild disorientation depending on how use you are to VR and your sensitivity to motion sickness but I think this is the closest I will ever get to experiencing whats its like to be an Astronaut. I can only imagine a game using these graphics and technique into a science fiction space game. I highly recommend downloading and experiencing what this is like.

One major complaint I have tho, I cannot push off from objects with my hands. My body goes through the floor or whatever device. The only way I can push off objects is if I use the grab and push feature. Realistically we not only would be able to go through the floors, our hands would be able to stop us or push off from an object like most physic based VR games. This issue isnt enough to take away a star but it does stand out a lot and I hope the Dev team realize this is a major issue. Also a smooth turning option would be a great idea as well.

BUT be warned, even if you have had no issues yet with VR sickness this game might cause you to experience it. Such as right away when I started to move I began to feel a bit uncomfortable. It got worse once things started to rotate as I lost my bearings and had to close my eyes several times to steady my balance. Funny enough you can grab onto the rails to stop things from spinning and move around, so the immersion of "saving" yourself via holding on is kind of neat I guess. After about ten minutes though I started to feel the need to pull off the goggles, which was the first time ever using VR. I pushed myself through it and things got a bit better but afterwards I felt a bit nauseous. Just a bit of caution.

PeteyPakDec 20 at 6:40 AM
Poor implementation

I cant comment on the content itself, I quit in frustration after the introduction, over the controls. When teaching you how to move, the movement controls are disabled, preventing you from trying it out yourself. You need to listen through a description of how to move while being prevented from moving. Its unpleasantly frustrating.

Movement uses the control stick direction, but the direction of the movement depends on where youre looking, and ignores the control stick orientation. It would seem to be more natural move in the direction the controller moves in.

The action of pointing and selecting things is done with the grip button, (which is already used for gripping), instead of the trigger button thats universally used for selecting things in the Quest menus and in the menus of this game.

I appreciate the full 3D orientation of the ship around you, but it clashes with the 2D diagram on the info palette, and the game cant seem to decide what to go with - you appear for the first time oriented with the station looking flat around you, then the world is thrown off-kilter while you are trying to learn the movement controls, which is not the right time for that. Making the first trip from one end of the station to the other, constrained in the plane of the diagram, would be better for concentrating on learning movement, then tell users theyre ready to explore and give them a slight kick off kilter after controls are learned, *that* would be a wow-moment. But also just appearing with the station already at an angle around you would be an improvement I feel.

I would definitely have preferred some visual aids, and give verbal descriptions only when needed.

The clunkiness of interaction makes this feel like an educational game rather than something intrinsically interesting. Repeat: Im not complaining about the content, which looks very good, Im complaining about the usability and experience which could definitely be improved.

mystickidSep 1, 2019 at 9:19 AM
Unglued at Last

Im still learning how to maneuver the Canadian Arm on the International Space Station. Theres a cargo vessel floating out there almost within my grasp waiting for me to bring it in to dock. Its not as easy as it looks. Once in awhile I cant help but loose my grip on the joystick and marvel at the curve of the Earth below me out the window.

It only took 50 some years to get here. Its just yet another unexpected gift that gaining 3-dimensional sight and access to virtual reality has given me. All thats missing from this once shattered dream is weightlessness. It Is right outta a childs dream. One often played with, loved at, lost to adulthood but never quite forgotten. The very first Space Camp ended it the day when our instructors, Lieutenants John and Andy, brought a docking simulator into our classroom. It was really just a rough-looking box of wood with a couple of levers in the front and a little rectangular window to look through, but to us it was the nose cone of a Gemini capsule looking out into space. Through the cross hairs was the docking grid on the snout of an Agena spacecraft, standing in at the time for a yet to be tested lunar module.

It wasnt known yet how the real objects would react in weightlessness. How would they come together? Would they repel or bounce off or just float apart? How does one guide them in and grapple them together? Maybe it wasnt even possible! Still every future mission depended on astronauts being able to dock in space. All the kids took the simulator very seriously. Everyone in turn tried it, some were uncoordinated, others too slow, but eventually they would all center the target and dock successfully.
Then it was my turn.

I couldnt do it. Everyone else went on to the next project; we had our final competition coming up, an egg reentry vehicle design contest. But I kept trying and failing, trying and failing the docking maneuver. Why cant I do this? For the first time, living in a 2-dimensional world instead of a 3-dimensional one wasnt just about bumping into full-length mirrors and saying excuse me. Everyone else would look at television, or a movie, or through a camera viewfinder and see one less dimension than they usually did. For me there had never been any difference. There had never been more than 2 dimensions. Was that why I couldnt dock the simulator?

Over and over again I tried until Lt. John shooed me away from it without saying a word. I went back and tried again. He put a table cloth over it. I snuck back under it to try again. They moved it out of reach in another room. Please, please, Lt. Andy, please let me try it again. I can do it. There must be a way. I dont wanna wash out. Please Lt. Andy, I can do it! Up close he seemed as tall as one of the rockets at the NY Worlds Fair. The young mans expression told me everything I didnt want to know. He added: Im not going to be an astronaut either, you know, honey. Im not a pilot. Im just a soldier. What he said glued me to Earth for sure. It reminded of a much more important reality than mine. More important than just my being earthbound forever. We were at war in Vietnam and Andy was a soldier.

Great but could use some tweaks

First of all great app. Its wonderful to be able to experience the layout of the ISS and a spacewalk first hand. The training explains everything very well and the mission waypoints get you where you need to be. The view of the Earth from the station and space is spectacular.

I only have two problems though, both relating to the controls and I really hope the developers read this as I dont know how to otherwise contact them. The major problem is the inability to invert the y axis on the right thumb stick. I am so used to this configuration in every game I play and the lack of an option is a startling omission in a first person experience where the view can be controlled with a thumb stick. A minor problem also has to do with the view controls and its the lack of a smooth movement option when controlling the view. I can work with the 30 degree snap movement but it is somewhat disorienting because this is quite obviously not how looking around works in real life and it makes controlling the experience more difficult than it has to be. I understand that snap movement helps some people with VR sickness which is why this and the ability to invert the y axis should be options.

Otherwise excellent experience especially for free and I encourage everyone to try it out. I do hope the developers read these reviews though and that theyll maybe address these concerns in an update.

obi2kenobiJul 20, 2019 at 8:41 AM
Too bad I'm stuck with gravity

Because the rest of it is pretty convincing! The inside of the ISS is quite detailed, and it's neat to watch a video about something on the ISS like the exercise bike then go check it out in VR.

Locomotion around the station is pretty awesome. You just grab rails or push and pull off any object or wall. Pretty fun to float around.

There are two "mini-games" associated with the experience. One is controlling the canada arm, and the other is going on a spacewalk (no walking of course, you just jetpack around). The spacewalk did reveal to me that the outside of the ISS looks quite rough compared to the inside, but its all still very beautiful and looking down at earth almost makes it feel like a star wars planet.

The spacewalk was probably the most unrealistic part physics wise. If i launched myself by grabbing hold of the station and pushing off, hitting my jets would instantly stop my momentum. Same if I was moving and grabbed the station i would stop instantly which isn't realistic.

But overall pretty fun experience. I didn't even 100% it but still spent at least an hour. Probably a $10 value here comparing it to other apps.

Cheers
